key_points: ICAO Annex 10, Volume II Phrase Meaning ACKNOWLEDGE “Let me know that you have received and understood this message
” AFFIRM “Yes
” APPROVED “Permission for proposed action granted
learning.explanation: ICAO Annex 10, Volume II Phrase Meaning ACKNOWLEDGE “Let me know that you have received and understood this message.” AFFIRM “Yes.” APPROVED “Permission for proposed action granted.” BREAK “I hereby indicate the separation between portions of the message.” (To be used where there is no clear distinction between the text and other portions of the message.) BREAK BREAK “I hereby indicate the separation between messages transmitted to different aircraft in a very busy environment.” CANCEL “Annul the previously transmitted clearance.” CONFIRM “I request verification of: (clearance, instruction, action, information).” CONTACT “Establish communications with.” CORRECT “True” or “Accurate” CORRECTION “An error has been made in this transmission (or message indicated). The correct version is.” DISREGARD “Ignore.” I SAY AGAIN “I repeat for clarity or emphasis.” GO AHEAD “Proceed with your message.” Note.— Not used whenever the possibility exists of misconstruing “GO AHEAD” as an authorization for an aircraft to proceed. The phrase “GO AHEAD” may be omitted and, in its place, a response made by using the calling aeronautical station’s call sign followed by the answering aeronautical station’s call sign. MONITOR “Listen out on (frequency).” NEGATIVE “No” or “Permission not granted” or “That is not correct” or “Not capable”. READ BACK “Repeat all, or the specified part, of this message back to me exactly as received.” RECLEARED “A change has been made to your last clearance and this new clearance supersedes your previous clearance or part thereof.” REPORT “Pass me the following information.” ROGER “I have received all of your last transmission.” Note.— Under no circumstances to be used in reply to a question requiring “READ BACK” or a direct answer in the affirmative (AFFIRM) or negative (NEGATIVE). SPEAK SLOWER “Reduce your rate of speech.” UNABLE “I cannot comply with your request, instruction, or clearance.” Note.— UNABLE is normally followed by a reason. STANDBY “Wait and I will call you.” Note.— The caller would normally re-establish contact if the delay is lengthy. STANDBY is not an approval or denial. WILCO (Abbreviation for “will comply”.) “I understand your message and will comply with it.” Note: We have created the above table based on the questions you may find in your exam, however the table is not extensive. Further radiotelephony words and phrases can be found in ICAO Annex 10, Volume II.

key_points: The Traffic Alert and Collision Avoidance System (TCAS), also known as the Airborne Collision Avoidance System (ACAS) is an airborne system designed to increase cockpit awareness of nearby aircraft and service as a last defense against mid-air collisions

The system monitors airspace around an aircraft for other transponder equipped aircraft that may present a collision threat and when it detects a collision threat, TCAS issues different resolution advisories in the vertical plane
Pilots are required to comply immediately with all RAs, even if the RAs are contrary to ATC clearances or instructions
learning.explanation: The Traffic Alert and Collision Avoidance System (TCAS), also known as the Airborne Collision Avoidance System (ACAS) is an airborne system designed to increase cockpit awareness of nearby aircraft and service as a last defense against mid-air collisions. The system monitors airspace around an aircraft for other transponder equipped aircraft that may present a collision threat and when it detects a collision threat, TCAS issues different resolution advisories in the vertical plane. Pilots are required to comply immediately with all RAs, even if the RAs are contrary to ATC clearances or instructions. If a pilot receives an RA, he/she is obliged to follow it, unless doing so would endanger the aircraft. The pilot should inform ATC using the phrase “TCAS RA” and ATC will only reply “ROGER”. When returning to the assigned clearance or when the assigned clearance has been resumed, the pilot should report it to the controller using the phrase “clear of conflict, returning to (assigned clearance)” or “clear of conflict, (assigned clearance) resumed”. TCAS RA takes priority over ATC instructions, pilots should report that they are unable to comply with a clearance as a result of a TCAS alert using the phrase “unable TCAS RA”.

key_points: The PTT button refers to the Push-To-Talk button used for the transmission of voice messages over the radio frequency
When the PTT button is pressed, the pilot's microphone becomes active, allowing them to speak and transmit their voice to the ATC or other aircraft tuned to the same frequency
Once the PTT button is released, the microphone stops transmitting, and the pilot is able to listen to incoming communications from ATC or other aircraft
learning.explanation: The PTT button refers to the Push-To-Talk button used for the transmission of voice messages over the radio frequency. When the PTT button is pressed, the pilot's microphone becomes active, allowing them to speak and transmit their voice to the ATC or other aircraft tuned to the same frequency. Once the PTT button is released, the microphone stops transmitting, and the pilot is able to listen to incoming communications from ATC or other aircraft. An irritating and potentially dangerous situation in radiotelephony is a “stuck” microphone button. Operators should always ensure that the button is released after a transmission and the microphone placed in an appropriate place ensuring that it will not inadvertently be switched on. Should your microphone button be stuck in the "transmit" position, your radio will keep transmitting permanently, and since VHF communications are not telephone communications, nobody else will be able to talk on that particular frequency, although they will hear everything you say.

content.question: At the Tenerif’s Accident of 1977 two aircraft collided when one aircraft started the take off run while the other was taxiing onto the runway (taxiway was occupied). The aircraft taking off reported, “we are now at take-off” and the tower replied “OK…, stand by for take-off. I will call you”. Simultaneously, the other aircraft taxiing onto the runway reported, “ah…hu..we are still taxiing down the runway”. What is the reason these last two transmissions might NOT have reached the take-off aircraft?

options.A: If neither of the two messages was received, there must have been a failure of the receiver of the aircraft taking off. There is NO other possible explanation.
options.B: A technical reason is NOT to be suspected. Most likely, the crew was absorbed by the takeoff and probably failed to notice the calls.
options.C: As simultaneous transmissions on one frequency are NOT possible, they can block each other out. NOTHING or just interference noises might have been heard instead.
options.D: The message of the Tower must have been received. The transmissions of ground stations have a general priority to supersede other simultaneous transmissions.

key_points: When two or more transmissions occur simultaneously on the same frequency, depending on relative difference between the strengths and timing of the two incoming signals, the local architecture, etc; the Air Traffic Controller hears one message clearly, some garbling or some partial overlap of the messages
The absence of a read-back from the pilot should be treated as a blocked transmission and prompt a request to repeat or confirm the message
The absence of response from the controller should be treated as an evidence of blocked transmission and the pilot should repeat the message
learning.explanation: When two or more transmissions occur simultaneously on the same frequency, depending on relative difference between the strengths and timing of the two incoming signals, the local architecture, etc; the Air Traffic Controller hears one message clearly, some garbling or some partial overlap of the messages. The absence of a read-back from the pilot should be treated as a blocked transmission and prompt a request to repeat or confirm the message. The absence of response from the controller should be treated as an evidence of blocked transmission and the pilot should repeat the message. At the Tenerif’ s accident, if the two transmissions were stated simultaneously, it was impossible for both of them to be transmitted. The result was that they either cancelled each other out, or some parts of one of the messages were heard without enough strength to be received, or the message was heard as an interference noise.

Therefore, 2400 = two four zero zero. 5.2.1.4.1.5 All numbers used in the transmission of altitude, cloud height, visibility and runway visual range (RVR) information, which contain whole hundreds and whole thousands, shall be transmitted by pronouncing each digit in the number of hundreds or thousands followed by the HUNDRED or THOUSAND as appropriate. Combinations of thousands and whole hundreds shall be transmitted by pronouncing each digit in the number of thousands followed by the word THOUSAND followed by the number of hundreds followed by the word HUNDRED. In this case, Altitude: hundreds are spoken as "hundred". Therefore, 2400 = two thousand four hundred.

content.question: When should the term "take-off" be used by a pilot?

options.A: To inform the control tower that the aircraft is ready for departure.
options.B: Never, it is used only by the control tower.
options.C: To acknowledge take-off clearance.
options.D: When the aircraft has moved onto the active runway.

key_points: Nor controllers or pilots shall use the phrase "take-off" unless it is in the actual take-off clearance
If the pilot misunderstands the radio transmission and he/she believes that they are cleared for take-off, a runway incursion and/or a serious accident may occur
This is why pilots shall report when they are ready, with the phrases: "ready" or "ready for departure"
learning.explanation: Nor controllers or pilots shall use the phrase "take-off" unless it is in the actual take-off clearance. If the pilot misunderstands the radio transmission and he/she believes that they are cleared for take-off, a runway incursion and/or a serious accident may occur. This is why pilots shall report when they are ready, with the phrases: "ready" or "ready for departure". ICAO Doc 4444 7.9.3 Take-off clearance 7.9.3.3 The expression TAKE-OFF shall only be used in radiotelephony when an aircraft is cleared for take-off or when cancelling a take-off clearance. 7.9.3.4 Subject to 7.9.3.2, the take-off clearance shall be issued when the aircraft is ready for take-off and at or approaching the departure runway, and the traffic situation permits. To reduce the potential for misunderstanding, the take-off clearance shall include the designator of the departure runway.

learning.explanation: ICAO Doc 9432 (MANUAL OF RADIOTELEPHONY) 2.3 TRANSMISSION OF LETTERS 2.3.1 To expedite communications, the use of phonetic spelling should be dispensed with if there is no risk of this affecting correct reception and intelligibility of the message. The Radiotelephony Spelling Alphabet is used primarily to ensure clear and precise communication over radio. Each letter of the English alphabet is assigned a specific word to ensure that each letter is clearly understood when spoken, particularly in noisy or poor communication conditions. This helps to avoid confusion that can arise from similar-sounding letters. The call sign BEG corresponds to the following words: B → Bravo E → Echo G → Golf This is a confusing question with similar answers: 'No, because 'Blue' is not a standard phonetic alphabet word' is technically correct but doesn't provide the correct term. 'No, it should be 'Bravo Echo Golf' identifies the mistake and corrects it by providing the appropriate phonetic term.

content.question: A pilot transmits the term 'blocked' on the radio. This means that...

options.A: There is an emergency going on and you should not use your radio until the emergency communication ends.
options.C: Two or more simultaneous transmissions occurred at the same time.

key_points: Communication directly between pilots and ATC may face disruptions when two or more radio transmissions occur, simultaneously, on the same frequency which can effectively block all or part of the intended messages

In this context ‘simultaneous’ is defined as two or more transmissions that overlap in such a way that the controller is not aware that more than one transmission has occurred leading to a potential safety hazard
In cases of simultaneous transmissions, it can be beneficial for the controller (or another pilot, if the controller's transmission is affected) to highlight the situation by using the term "blocked"
learning.explanation: Communication directly between pilots and ATC may face disruptions when two or more radio transmissions occur, simultaneously, on the same frequency which can effectively block all or part of the intended messages. In this context ‘simultaneous’ is defined as two or more transmissions that overlap in such a way that the controller is not aware that more than one transmission has occurred leading to a potential safety hazard. In cases of simultaneous transmissions, it can be beneficial for the controller (or another pilot, if the controller's transmission is affected) to highlight the situation by using the term "blocked". Although not official procedure, some pilots make a practice of alerting controllers and other pilots to an apparent blocked or garbled transmission by saying “Blocked” immediately afterwards. This practice should be encouraged.

learning.explanation: The logon is the first step in the data link process. A logon, initiated either by the flight crew or automatically following a contact request from another ATS unit, is performed prior to the ATS unit establishing a CPDLC and/or ADS-C connection. The purpose of the logon is to provide the ATS unit with: a) the information on ATS data link applications supported by the aircraft system (e.g. CPDLC, ADS-C); b) the associated version numbers of the ATS data link applications; c) the unique identification of the aircraft; and d) additional relevant aircraft information required to allow the ATS unit to correlate the logon information with the aircraft’s corresponding flight plan.

Consider the following initial transmission after a frequency change: A6-ETT: "Chester radar, alpha six tango tango, maintaining 3000 feet, heading 310." Chester radar: "Alpha tango tango, roger, maintain heading." Which of the following statements are correct?
1. The pilot should not have abbreviated the call sign first

key_points: At initial contact, when establishing communications, an aircraft should use the full call sign of both the aircraft and the aeronautical station
An aircraft shall use its abbreviated call sign only after it has been addressed in this manner by the aeronautical station
Therefore, the pilot should have used the following call sign: "A6-ETT" = Alpha Six Echo Tango Tango
learning.explanation: At initial contact, when establishing communications, an aircraft should use the full call sign of both the aircraft and the aeronautical station. An aircraft shall use its abbreviated call sign only after it has been addressed in this manner by the aeronautical station. Therefore, the pilot should have used the following call sign: "A6-ETT" = Alpha Six Echo Tango Tango. And NOT Alpha Six Tango Tango. Furthermote, the latter is also not the correct abbreviated call sign. The call sign "A6-ETT" consists of the characters corresponding to the registration marking of the aircraft. After satisfactory communication has been established, and provided that no confusion is likely to occur, the call sign may be abbreviated as follows: the first and at least the last two characters of the aircraft registration => A-TT "Alpha Tango Tango". Based on the above, we can confidently confirm that Chester radar abbreviated the call sign correctly.

learning.explanation: SELCAL is abbreviated for Selective Calling System and it is used in international aviation to alert flight crews of transmission directed to them as they fly transoceanic routes. SECAL operates on HF or VHF frequency bands. An individual aircrafts owns its unique SELCAL code which is used by the controller to address the SELCAL on board of the aircraft. The code is converted into four designated audio tones, then it is broadcast and every aircraft, which has a SELCAL system, receives it. The decoding system reads the tones and triggers a warning for the flight crew if it recognizes its own code. SPEAK SLOWER “Reduce your rate of speech.” UNABLE “I cannot comply with your request, instruction, or clearance.” Note.— UNABLE is normally followed by a reason. STANDBY “Wait and I will call you.” Note.— The caller would normally re-establish contact if the delay is lengthy. STANDBY is not an approval or denial. key_points: Controller-pilot data link communications (CPDLC)
A means of communication between controller and pilot, using data link for ATC communications
The CPDLC is a FANS application that consists of transmitting datalink formatted messages between the pilot (the aircraft) and the ATC controller or the Company (the ground)
learning.explanation: Controller-pilot data link communications (CPDLC). A means of communication between controller and pilot, using data link for ATC communications. The CPDLC is a FANS application that consists of transmitting datalink formatted messages between the pilot (the aircraft) and the ATC controller or the Company (the ground). A message sent by the aircraft to the ground is called a downlink message, the opposite is called an uplink message. Datalink messages may concern various requests such as route modifications, speed changes, voice contact requests (ex: transfer of ATC center), emergency messages (MAYDAY), crossing constraints, pre-departure clearances, ATIS, oceanic clearances, etc. Datalink messages can be sent using different media such as HF datalink, VHF datalink, or SATCOM. The SATCOM has the fastest rate of transmission, while the HF datalink has the slowest. The SATCOM is particularly good as there is no line-of-sight limitation and no variable quality of signals disturbed by ionospheric conditions, however, this media is not installed on all airplanes. The ground routing of the ATC datalink communications is performed by service providers (SITA, ARINC) that can be interconnected to provide continuity of the transmissions. The ACARS allows air/ground datalink communications for Airline Operational and Air Traffic Communications (AOC and ATC). It stands for Aircraft Communications, Addressing and Reporting System and is included in the aircraft Management Unit (or MU or CMU). ACARS messages are transmitted from the ground to the aircraft and vice-versa using several radio communication media such as VHF, HF, SATCOM. In the early days of the ACARS, it was using only VHF for transmission, but nowadays advanced technology allows the ACARS to chose itself the transmitting method depending on the current coverage and flown airspace.

content.question: What does good transmitting technique mean?

options.A: Keep the microphone far away since it improves the readability.
options.B: Speak very loudly into the microphone.
options.C: Transmit long messages without interruption in order to avoid blocking the frequency for a long time.
options.D: Use a normal conversation tone, speak clearly and distinctly.

key_points: TRANSMITTING TECHNIQUE Transmissions shall be conducted concisely in a normal conversational tone
Speech transmitting technique should be such that the highest possible intelligibility is incorporated in each transmission
Fulfilment of this aim requires that air crew and ground personnel should: a) enunciate each word clearly and distinctly; b) maintain an even rate of speech not exceeding 100 words per minute
learning.explanation: TRANSMITTING TECHNIQUE Transmissions shall be conducted concisely in a normal conversational tone. Speech transmitting technique should be such that the highest possible intelligibility is incorporated in each transmission. Fulfilment of this aim requires that air crew and ground personnel should: a) enunciate each word clearly and distinctly; b) maintain an even rate of speech not exceeding 100 words per minute. When a message is transmitted to an aircraft and its contents need to be recorded the speaking rate should be at a slower rate to allow for the writing process. A slight pause preceding and following numerals makes them easier to understand; c) maintain the speaking volume at a constant level; d) be familiar with the microphone operating techniques particularly in relation to the maintenance of a constant distance from the microphone if a modulator with a constant level is not used; e) suspend speech temporarily if it becomes necessary to turn the head away from the microphone.

key_points: Vectoring
Provision of navigational guidance to aircraft in the form of specific headings, based on the use of an ATS surveillance system
When an aircraft is being vectored, the ATC has the responsibility to provide altitudes that ensure obstacle clearance
learning.explanation: Vectoring. Provision of navigational guidance to aircraft in the form of specific headings, based on the use of an ATS surveillance system. When an aircraft is being vectored, the ATC has the responsibility to provide altitudes that ensure obstacle clearance. However, if the altitudes given by the ATC do not ensure the required ground clearance, the pilot should refuse to follow them. ICAO Doc 4444 - Air Traffic Management 8.6.5 Vectoring 8.6.5.2 When vectoring an IFR flight and when giving an IFR flight a direct routing which takes the aircraft off an ATS route, the controller shall issue clearances such that the prescribed obstacle clearance will exist at all times until the aircraft reaches the point where the pilot will resume own navigation. When necessary, the relevant minimum vectoring altitude shall include a correction for low temperature effect. Note 1.— When an IFR flight is being vectored, the pilot may be unable to determine the aircraft’s exact position in respect to obstacles in this area and consequently the altitude which provides the required obstacle clearance. Detailed obstacle clearance criteria are contained in PANS-OPS (Doc 8168), Volumes I and II. See also 8.6.8.2. ICAO Doc 8168 - Aircraft Operations 1.3.4 Vectors Pilots should not accept vectors during departure unless: a) they are above the minimum altitude(s)/height(s) required to maintain obstacle clearance in the event of engine failure. This relates to engine failure between V1 and minimum sector altitude or the end of the contingency procedure as appropriate; or b) the departure route is non-critical with respect to obstacle clearance.

learning.explanation: An irritating and potentially dangerous situation in radiotelephony is a “stuck” microphone button. Operators should always ensure that the button is released after a transmission and the microphone placed in an appropriate place ensuring that it will not inadvertently be switched on. Should your microphone button be stuck in the "transmit" position, your radio will keep transmitting permanently, and since VHF communications are not telephone communications, nobody else will be able to talk on that particular frequency, although they will hear everything you say.

content.question:
You are flying in an area where Controller-Pilot Data Link Communications (CPDLC) are being used and you send the following message:
‘‘REQUEST WEATHER DEVIATION UP TO 15 NM LEFT OF ROUTE’’
Which of these options is the most probable initial CPDLC response from ATC?

options.A: "ROGER"
options.C: "WILCO"

key_points: For this question, you have to imaine what would occur if you requested such a weather deviation from a controller over standard VHF radio
They cannot respond with "ROGER" or "WILCO" as they would not work for this request, and "AFFIRM" would not be a suitable response in order to approve this change in routing/clearance
To issue a change like this, ATC would have to read out the deviation routing to the aircraft, who would then read it back
learning.explanation: For this question, you have to imaine what would occur if you requested such a weather deviation from a controller over standard VHF radio. They cannot respond with "ROGER" or "WILCO" as they would not work for this request, and "AFFIRM" would not be a suitable response in order to approve this change in routing/clearance. To issue a change like this, ATC would have to read out the deviation routing to the aircraft, who would then read it back. This would work the same for CPDLC communications, so "AFFIRM" cannot be correct. This leaves only "STANDBY" which is certainly an acceptable response to such a request, whether over VHF or CPDLC.

learning.explanation: SELCAL is abbreviated for Selective Calling System and it is used in international aviation to alert flight crews of transmission directed to them as they fly transoceanic routes. SECAL operates on HF or VHF frequency bands. An individual aircrafts owns its unique SELCAL code which is used by the controller to address the SELCAL on board of the aircraft. The code is converted into four designated audio tones, then it is broadcast and every aircraft, which has a SELCAL system, receives it. The decoding system reads the tones and triggers a warning for the flight crew if it recognizes its own code. When the conditional clearance involves a departing aircraft and an arriving aircraft, it is important that the departing aircraft correctly identifies the arriving aircraft on which the conditional clearance is based. Reference to the arriving aircraft type may be insufficient and it may be necessary to add a description of the colour or the company name to ensure correct identification. A conditional clearance shall be given as follows: 1) call sign; 2) the condition; 3) the clearance; 4) brief reiteration of the condition. Example: “SAS 941, BEHIND DC9 ON SHORT FINAL, LINE UP BEHIND”. Note: The term "behind" is used twice to avoid any possible confusion and make sure the pilot will line up and wait after the landing aircraft.

key_points: Controller-pilot data link communications (CPDLC)
A means of communication between controller and pilot, using data link for ATC communications
ICAO Doc 10037 Global Operational Data Link (GOLD) Manual 1
learning.explanation: Controller-pilot data link communications (CPDLC). A means of communication between controller and pilot, using data link for ATC communications. ICAO Doc 10037 Global Operational Data Link (GOLD) Manual 1.2.3. CPDLC connection management 1.2.3.1.1. The purpose of a CPDLC connection is to allow the exchange of CPDLC messages between an aircraft and an ATS unit (active connection), and also to provide an advance connection with the next ATS unit (inactive connection). An aircraft can have a maximum of two CPDLC connections established concurrently, each with a different ATS unit. Only one CPDLC connection can be active at any given time; any second connection is inactive. 1.2.3.3.2. The ATS unit initiates a CPDLC connection by sending a CPDLC connection request to the aircraft as 1.2.3.3.3. Provided there is no existing CPDLC connection, the aircraft system: a) accepts the connection request; b) establishes this CPDLC connection as the active connection; and c) responds with a CPDLC connection confirm. 1.2.3.5. Transferring CPDLC connections 1.2.3.5.1. Under normal circumstances, the CDA will initiate a CPDLC transfer to an adjacent ATS unit as the aircraft transits from the current ATS unit to another CPDLC-capable ATS unit. These transfers are normally automatic, without flight crew action. “Disconnected from LOVV. Connecting to LOVL”: This transmission indicates that the aircraft's CPDLC system has autonomously managed the transition between the CPDLC ground stations. LOVV refers to the control center that the aircraft was previously connected to, and LOVL is the new control center it has connected to. This automatic handover is a standard process in CPDLC to maintain continuous communication as the aircraft moves through different airspace sectors.

Traffic Advisory (TA) is indicated on the navigation display of glass cockpit aircraft by an amber full circle labelled with an arrow which indicates the vertical movement of the traffic and two digits giving distance information, and by an aural alert "Traffic, traffic"
learning.explanation: TCAS II equipment provides two types of advisories to pilots: Resolution Advisories (RAs) and Traffic Advisories (TAs). These are defined as follows: Traffic advisory (TA) is an indication given to the flight crew that a certain intruder is a potential threat. Traffic Advisory (TA) is indicated on the navigation display of glass cockpit aircraft by an amber full circle labelled with an arrow which indicates the vertical movement of the traffic and two digits giving distance information, and by an aural alert "Traffic, traffic". Visual contact shall be established with the conflicting traffic and the pilot should be prepared for a RA. ” AFFIRM “Yes
” APPROVED “Permission for proposed action granted
learning.explanation: ICAO Annex 10, Volume II Phrase Meaning ACKNOWLEDGE “Let me know that you have received and understood this message.” AFFIRM “Yes.” APPROVED “Permission for proposed action granted.” BREAK “I hereby indicate the separation between portions of the message.” (To be used where there is no clear distinction between the text and other portions of the message.) BREAK BREAK “I hereby indicate the separation between messages transmitted to different aircraft in a very busy environment.” CANCEL “Annul the previously transmitted clearance.” CONFIRM “I request verification of: (clearance, instruction, action, information).” CONTACT “Establish communications with.” CORRECT “True” or “Accurate” CORRECTION “An error has been made in this transmission (or message indicated). The correct version is.” DISREGARD “Ignore.” I SAY AGAIN “I repeat for clarity or emphasis.” GO AHEAD “Proceed with your message.” Note.— Not used whenever the possibility exists of misconstruing “GO AHEAD” as an authorization for an aircraft to proceed. The phrase “GO AHEAD” may be omitted and, in its place, a response made by using the calling aeronautical station’s call sign followed by the answering aeronautical station’s call sign. MONITOR “Listen out on (frequency).” NEGATIVE “No” or “Permission not granted” or “That is not correct” or “Not capable”. READ BACK “Repeat all, or the specified part, of this message back to me exactly as received.” RECLEARED “A change has been made to your last clearance and this new clearance supersedes your previous clearance or part thereof.” REPORT “Pass me the following information.” ROGER “I have received all of your last transmission.” Note.— Under no circumstances to be used in reply to a question requiring “READ BACK” or a direct answer in the affirmative (AFFIRM) or negative (NEGATIVE). SPEAK SLOWER “Reduce your rate of speech.” UNABLE “I cannot comply with your request, instruction, or clearance.” Note.— UNABLE is normally followed by a reason. STANDBY “Wait and I will call you.” Note.— The caller would normally re-establish contact if the delay is lengthy. STANDBY is not an approval or denial. WILCO (Abbreviation for “will comply”.) “I understand your message and will comply with it.” Note: We have created the above table based on the questions you may find in your exam, however the table is not extensive. Further radiotelephony words and phrases can be found in ICAO Annex 10, Volume II.

learning.explanation: ICAO Doc 9432 11.1 SELECTIVE CALLING (SELCAL) 11.1.1 SELCAL is a system by which voice calling is replaced by the transmission of coded tones on the frequency in use. Receipt of the assigned SELCAL code activates a calling system in the cockpit, and the need for a continuous listening watch by the pilot is obviated. learning.explanation: PRE-DEPARTURE MANOEUVRING Meticulous care has been taken to ensure that the phraseology which is to be employed during the pre-departure manoeuvres cannot be interpreted as a take-off clearance or instruction to enter the runway. This is to avoid any misunderstanding in the granting or acknowledgement of take-off clearances and indeed any instruction to use the runway e.g. Line-up and the serious consequences that could result. In addition, any instruction to use a runway shall include the designator of the runway. When passing the clearance, the runway designator should be stated before the clearance, e.g. (Callsign) Runway 06, cleared for take-off. The read-back shall then include the runway designator as well as the phrase "cleared for take-off". Please see attached figure.

SPEAK SLOWER “Reduce your rate of speech.” UNABLE “I cannot comply with your request, instruction, or clearance.” Note.— UNABLE is normally followed by a reason. STANDBY “Wait and I will call you.” Note.— The caller would normally re-establish contact if the delay is lengthy. STANDBY is not an approval or denial. WILCO (Abbreviation for “will comply”.) “I understand your message and will comply with it.” Note: We have created the above table based on the questions you may find in your exam, however the table is not extensive. Further radiotelephony words and phrases can be found in ICAO Annex 10, Volume II.

learning.explanation: ICAO Annex 3 — Meteorological Service for International Air Navigation CHAPTER 1 - DEFINITIONS Automatic dependent surveillance — contract (ADS-C). A means by which the terms of an ADS-C agreement will be exchanged between the ground system and the aircraft, via a data link, specifying under what conditions ADS-C reports would be initiated, and what data would be contained in the reports. Note.— The abbreviated term “ADS contract” is commonly used to refer to ADS event contract, ADS demand contract, ADS periodic contract or an emergency mode. The ADS (Automatic Dependent Surveillance) is a FANS application that consists in automatically sending aircraft surveillance data to the ATC. The set of data to downlink is defined automatically, without any crew action. The different types of ADS contracts can be: Periodic – at periodic time intervals. On demand – when asked for by the ATC. On event – whenever a specified event occurs. Emergency messages can also be sent through the ADS application. When a MAYDAY datalink message is sent to the ATC, the ADS contract is switched to a high periodic reporting rate.

content.question: An aircraft's crew decide to divert following an engine failure. They are currrently flying over several adequate airports and need to select a diversion option. What would be the quickest way to obtain weather information for all these airports?

options.C: Obtain information from the Air Traffic Services Unit (ATSU).
options.D: Contact each airport’s control tower directly.

key_points: While in the air, the main sources for weather information are: 1
Air Traffic Control - you can ask for the weather on the radio 2
ATIS (Automatic Terminal Information Service) - continuous recorded message of an aerodrome's weather on a discrete frequency
learning.explanation: While in the air, the main sources for weather information are: 1. Air Traffic Control - you can ask for the weather on the radio 2. ATIS (Automatic Terminal Information Service) - continuous recorded message of an aerodrome's weather on a discrete frequency. 3. VOLMET - continuous and repetitive voice broadcast covering an area and several airports' current METAR, SPECI, TAF and SIGMET. In this question, the crew need to collect the weather information for a number of airports in order to decide on a diversion option. The clue in the question is 'the quickest way to obtain weather information'. Calling several airports on the radio to ask for individual weather reports would take time and is normally not practical. ATC at major airports would not have the time to issue such reports. Selecting ATIS is an option but it would take time to individually collect the reports for several airports, and there is the question of being in range to receive the signal. VOLMET is the quickest option and using D-VOLMET (Datalink) ensures no problem with radio range.

content.question: While crossing a large mountain range, you encounter moderate turbulence. Is there an obligation to report this?

options.B: If an air-ground data link is available, a special aircraft observation must be reported. If only voice communication is available no report should be made, to avoid frequency congestion.
options.C: Yes, a special aircraft observation shall be made by air-ground datalink. Where air-ground data link is not available it shall be reported via voice communication.
options.D: No. Reporting is obligatory in case of severe turbulence, or in case of severe mountain wave associated with moderate turbulence.

Note.— Pre-eruption volcanic activity in this context means unusual and/or increasing volcanic activity which could presage a volcanic eruption. In addition, in the case of transonic and supersonic flight: i) moderate turbulence; or j) hail; or k) cumulonimbus clouds.

All air-reports shall be reported as soon as is practicable.4.12.3 Contents of special air-reports 4.12.3.1 Special air-reports shall be made by all aircraft whenever the following conditions are encountered or observed: a) moderate or severe turbulence; or b) moderate or severe icing; or c) severe mountain wave; or d) thunderstorms, without hail that are obscured, embedded, widespread or in squall lines; or e) thunderstorms, with hail that are obscured, embedded, widespread or in squall lines; or f) heavy duststorm or heavy sandstorm; or g) volcanic ash cloud; or h) pre-eruption volcanic activity or a volcanic eruption. learning.explanation: ICAO Annex 3 Chapter 1. Definitions VOLMET. Meteorological information for aircraft in flight. Data link-VOLMET (D-VOLMET). Provision of current aerodrome routine meteorological reports (METAR) and aerodrome special meteorological reports (SPECI), aerodrome forecasts (TAF), SIGMET, special air-reports not covered by a SIGMET and, where available, AIRMET via data link. VOLMET broadcast. Provision, as appropriate, of current METAR, SPECI, TAF and SIGMET by means of continuous and repetitive voice broadcasts. D-VOLMET obtains weather information automatically in textual format from various data sources and converts it into a high-quality voice output. This output can then be provided to aircraft in flight via HF or VHF radio through continuous or regularly-scheduled broadcasts. Simultaneously, D-VOLMET can transmit a textual copy of the message directly to ACARS-equipped aircraft via datalink.

content.question:
Before departure the pilot is informed of changing weather conditions at the destination airport.
During the flight in the cruise, with approximately 500 NM to go, the pilot wishes to check the destination weather. Where/how could this information be obtained?

options.A: ATIS using the designated frequency of an airport en-route, on Very High Frequencies (VHF).
options.B: D-ATIS by using Satcom and data link equipment such as ACARS.

key_points: “ATIS on High Frequencies (HF)
” And “ATIS using the designated frequency of an airport en-route, on Very High Frequencies (VHF)
” Incorrect
learning.explanation: “ATIS on High Frequencies (HF).” And “ATIS using the designated frequency of an airport en-route, on Very High Frequencies (VHF).” Incorrect. Automatic Terminal Information Service (ATIS) is a continuous broadcast of pre-recorded information at a selected airport. ATIS is typically broadcasted over a specific VHF frequency. => Listening out for an ATIS en-route will be of no help for a destination which is 500 NM away. “the scheduled VOLMET on Super High Frequencies (SHF).” Incorrect. VOLMET is meteorological information about multiple aerodromes in a certain region which is sent to aircraft during flight by a pre-recorded voice broadcast. VOLMET is broadcasted on VHF and HF (not SHF). We are left with “D-ATIS by using Satcom and data link equipment such as ACARS.” => D-ATIS is the provision of ATIS via data link.

learning.explanation: Wind direction is the direction from which the wind blows. In aviation, wind directions are expressed in degrees in reference to the North Pole (called true north) or to the North Magnetic Pole (called magnetic north). The aircraft has no data link

'D-ATIS' --> INCORRECT. The aircraft does not have data link. 'VOLMET - VHF' --> INCORRECT. VHF may not be available on an oceanic flight due to range limitations. 'VOLMET - HF' --> CORRECT. A VOLMET broadcast provides current METAR, SPECI, TAF and SIGMET information by means of continuous and repetitive voice broadcasts. HF would be an appropriate source in mid ocean. 'Request from ATC via voice communication' --> INCORRECT. Obtaining the weather for several airports would be impracticable via voice communications. There is also the question of range limitations on VHF due to being an oceanic flight. ICAO Annex 3 11.6.1 Continuous VOLMET broadcasts, normally on very high frequencies (VHF), shall contain current METAR and SPECI, together with trend forecasts where available. 11.6.2 Scheduled VOLMET broadcasts, normally on high frequencies (HF), shall contain current METAR and SPECI, together with trend forecasts where available and, where so determined by regional air navigation agreement, TAF and SIGMET.

learning.explanation: AIR-GROUND COMMUNICATIONS FAILURE An aircraft equipped with an SSR transponder is expected to operate the transponder on Mode A Code 7600 to indicate that it has experienced air-ground communication failure. If the failure occurs in VFR conditions, or if VFR conditions are encountered after the failure, each pilot must continue the flight under VFR and land as soon as practicable. It is not intended that the requirement to “land as soon as practicable” be construed to mean “as soon as possible.” Pilots retain the prerogative of exercising their best judgment and are not required to land at an unauthorized airport, at an airport unsuitable for the type of aircraft flown, or to land only minutes short of their intended destination. content.question:
Here is an extract of an exchange of radio-communication between the pilot of F-GTPO and Lille Tower: "F-PO, squawk 6101." "6101, F-PO." "F-PO, radar identified, cleared to Lille via route SA then leave controlled airspace via route N." "Cleared to Lille via route SA then leave controlled airspace via route N, F-PO." After a short while, F-PO is entering controlled airspace. "F-PO, Lille Tower, radio check 118.550." No answer. "F-PO, Lille Tower, if you read me, squawk IDENT." No answer but the controller`s radar shows that IDENT has been operated.
Assume that specific procedures for communication failure procedures have NOT been established for Lille Tower.
Which of the following statements are correct?
1. F-PO shall exit controlled airspace as soon as possible because he/she has a communication failure
2. F-PO is a controlled flight and must continue its transit to follow its clearance, unless this is incompatible with the regulation applicable for communication failure
3. F-PO will NOT receive any instruction from Lille Tower that will alter its transit clearance, other traffic will be instructed away from F-PO to maintain separation as applicable
4. F-PO may receive additional instructions from Lille Tower and the clearances can be acknowledged by operating the transponder

options.A: 1 and 3
options.C: 2 and 3

key_points: The question text is quite extensive
We will try to keep the explanation as simple and straight forward as possible
F-PO is a controlled flight, following a flight plan
learning.explanation: The question text is quite extensive. We will try to keep the explanation as simple and straight forward as possible. F-PO is a controlled flight, following a flight plan. If the aircraft continues to fly according to the flight plan it will be easier for ATC to estimate its position. Therefore, the aircraft shall continue its transit to follow its clearance, unless this is incompatible with the regulation application for communication failure. Statement 2 => Correct. F-PO is able to hear ATC, therefore they may receive additional instructions from Lille Tower and the clearances can be acknowledged by operating the transponder. Statement 4 => Correct.

content.question: During flight, the flight crew hears a click on the ATC frequency but no voice. Nevertheless the frequency is blocked. What is most likely the reason?

options.A: The modulating wave is received but the carrier wave is missing.
options.B: An interference with another station calling has occurred.
options.C: The aircraft communications equipment has failed.
options.D: The carrier wave is received but is not modulated.

key_points: When we want to send information via radio waves, we have to modulate the carrier wave somehow, this is the process of adding information to it
There are a few ways to do this
In the early days of radio, it was done by sending pulse of the carrier wave as morse code, pulse modulation
learning.explanation: When we want to send information via radio waves, we have to modulate the carrier wave somehow, this is the process of adding information to it. There are a few ways to do this. In the early days of radio, it was done by sending pulse of the carrier wave as morse code, pulse modulation. These days we can modulate the amplitude of the carrier wave, to carry our information, or we can modulate the frequency slightly, to carry information also. Amplitude modulation is easier to do and far easier to represent visually, as shown above. The peaks and troughs of our carrier wave are modified to create our information wave over the top of each peak, and the same information wave under each trough. The wave over the peaks is one sideband, and the wave under the troughs is the other sideband. These signals are carried along by the carrier wave, and then decoded in a receiver unit back to their original state, giving voice messages in the case of VHF. If a transmitter was faulty, it may not be able to encode the voice message information onto the carrier wave, and so may be able to send the carrier wave only, with no modulation. This would sound like clicks, or crackles down the radio, similar to what can be heard when a pilot presses the Push To Talk (PTT) button but says nothing. This carrier wave can be used to send signals in morse code if necessary, effectively going back to the days of pulse modulation.

learning.explanation: The emergency frequency (121.5 MHz) is specifically designated for distress and emergency communications by aircraft in need of immediate assistance. Aircraft in distress can use the emergency frequency to transmit a distress call and signal that they need immediate assistance. Air Traffic Control (ATC) plays a vital role in coordinating the response to the emergency. Once ATC is aware of the situation, they will coordinate with relevant authorities, including search and rescue services and ground-based emergency personnel, to respond to the incident. Ground-based emergency services, such as Police, Fire Departments, and Forest Fire Protection, will be notified by ATC or other relevant authorities about the crash and the location. They will then respond to the incident to provide assistance and carry out necessary rescue and recovery operations. The emergency frequency is used by any official personnel who are helping the aircraft, so the answer "Police, ATC and Forest Fire Protection" is chosen as the correct one. Here is the definition of distress and urgency by ICAO Annex 10: MAYDAY Distress: a condition of being threatened by grave and imminent danger and of requiring immediate assistance. This is a bit tricky, the flight is not in grave danger but someone onboard is and that person may require immediate medical assistance upon landing (this is not explicit in the question text). If you were to ask me, I would declare PAN PAN. For following reasons: - I will get a priority over all other traffic, except for aircraft in distress (rightfully so) - Mayday would start opening options I won't use (opening of closed runways and airports, etc.). While medical emergency on board, the safety of the flight shall not be put in a jeopardy. We need priority, but not at the cost of safety, normal landing will be performed. - Mayday will trigger emergency protocols at airports, preparing for crash landing (EHAM, highway closures), which we don't need. - What we need is to land at nearest suitable airport without delay, taxi to a stand (close to the runway) and get medics in for the passenger. learning.explanation: Essentially, the Range is determined by the position & length of the Antenna and attenuation: As far as the positioning is concerned, a VHF signal travels in a straight line and therefore is unable to be reflected off the ionosphere, as lower frequency signals are. Due to the range being restricted to ''line of sight'', when other vessels pass behind the curve of the earth, the connection is lost. So, the higher above sea level the antenna is, the greater range the VHF device will have. Attenuation is the term given to the loss of signal strength in a radio wave as it travels outward from the transmitter. It limits the range of radio signals. Higher frequencies suffer from higher attenuation – because they have a higher number of peaks which causes a higher number of energy fluctuations and energy loss over distance, being more prone to attenuation.

Polarization is used to describe the direction or plane of oscillation of the electrical field of an electromagnetic wave
The electromagnetic wave has two components - the electrical field (E) occuring in the vertical plane and the magnetic field (H) oscillations in the horizontal plane
learning.explanation: The band which is normally used for voice communication of the aeronautical mobile service is the VHF band. Polarization is used to describe the direction or plane of oscillation of the electrical field of an electromagnetic wave. The electromagnetic wave has two components - the electrical field (E) occuring in the vertical plane and the magnetic field (H) oscillations in the horizontal plane. The electric and magnetic fields oscillate at 90° with one another and the direction of propagation. Polarisation is affected by the plane of the aerial - a signal will only be effectively received if the receiving antenna is in the same alignment as the transmitting antenna: For efficient reception, if the transmitting antenna is vertical, the receiving aerial should also be vertical. If the transmitting aerial is horizontal, the receiving aerial should also be horizontal. A difference in polarity between the transmitter and the receiver reduces quality of reception.
